choices.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends
At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

 

The false statement about late decelerations among the given options is option C - At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline.

 

Typically, a late deceleration causes a fall in the fetal heart rate (FHR) by a depth of <10 to 20 bpm below the baseline. It is usually not accompanied by accelerations (Option D).

 

Late decelerations are smooth, gradual (Option B) symmetrical declines in the FHR that begin at or after the peak of uterine contraction and end only after the contraction has ended (Option A).

 

Late decelerations are usually indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia. Other causes of late decelerations include hypotension from epidural anesthesia, excessive use of oxytocin, maternal hypertension, diabetes, and placental abruption.

 

A late deceleration plus decreased variability in FHR is predictive of fetal acidemia and neonatal morbidity.

 

The given CTG shows late decelerations and their relationship with the uterine contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: This is correct. Late decelerations typically begin after the peak of the uterine contraction and persist beyond the end of the contraction. This is due to uteroplacental insufficiency and the delay in oxygen delivery to the fetus.

 

Option B. They are smooth and gradual: This is correct. Late decelerations show a smooth and gradual decrease in fetal heart rate, usually due to reduced oxygenation of the fetus caused by impaired placental function.

 

Option D. Not associated with accelerations: This is correct. Late decelerations are typically not associated with accelerations, which are indicative of fetal well-being. The absence of accelerations alongside late decelerations can suggest fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Late decelerations are characterized by a gradual, symmetrical decrease in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of uterine contractions and persists beyond their end. They are typically caused by uteroplacental insufficiency and are a concerning sign for fetal hypoxia.

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) She is susceptible to chicken pox

 

Anti-Varicella/Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)/Chickenpox IgG; Varicella immunity test

 

  • Negative: Indicates no detectable Varicella IgG antibodies. A negative results indicate no current or previous infection with Varicella virus. Such individuals are presumed to be susceptible to primary infection.
  • Equivocal: Equivocal results are indeterminate. Patient may or may not have immunity to Varicella Virus. It is not acceptable proof of immunity.
  • Positive: Indicates evidence of Varicella IgG antibodies and suggests past or current infection with Varicella virus. Antibodies obtained via acquired immunity or immunization and probable protection from clinical infection. (Immunity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is immune to zoster: Incorrect. Immunity to zoster (shingles) comes from having had a previous varicella (chicken pox) infection or vaccination. A negative antibody test indicates she has not had varicella.

 

Option B. She is susceptible to zoster: Incorrect. Susceptibility to zoster (shingles) typically arises from a reactivation of the varicella virus in individuals who have previously had chicken pox. A negative test means she has not had chicken pox, so she cannot develop zoster but is susceptible to chicken pox.

 

Option D. She is immune to chicken pox: Incorrect. A negative antibody test indicates she does not have immunity to chicken pox.
 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing renal transplant management was started on cyclosporine as part of the immunosuppressive regimen. Within a few weeks, the patient begins to show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. The treating physician suspects drug-induced cholestasis and considers the involvement of a specific cellular transporter. Which cellular transporter is most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis in this patient
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRP2

 

  • MRP2, also known as Multi-Drug Resistance-associated Protein 2 or ABCC2, is a membrane-bound transporter protein that belongs to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family of transporters.
  • This protein is primarily expressed in the liver, particularly in the canalicular membrane of hepatocytes, as well as in the kidneys, intestines, and other tissues.
  • MRP2 functions as an efflux pump, actively transporting a variety of substances out of cells including bile salts, bilirubin, glucuronides, and various drugs and their metabolites.
  • MRP2 plays a critical role in the efflux of bile salts and bilirubin into the bile canaliculus. Mutations or inhibition of MRP2 (by drugs like cyclosporine) can lead to cholestasis, a condition where bile cannot flow from the liver to the duodenum.
  • Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is a genetic disorder resulting from mutations in the MRP2 gene, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MDR 1: Multi-Drug Resistance Protein 1 (MDR 1 or P-glycoprotein) is more known for its role in drug resistance, not specifically for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis. While MDR-1 plays a role in drug metabolism and can be inhibited by cyclosporine, it is generally not implicated in the development of drug-induced cholestasis, which is more closely associated with MRP2 inhibition.

 

Option B. BRCA: The Breast Cancer Susceptibility Gene (BRCA) is not related to drug metabolism or cholestasis. It is mainly involved in DNA repair and cancer susceptibility.

 

Option D. OATP1B1: Organic Anion Transporting Polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1) is involved in drug uptake into the liver but is not the key player in cyclosporine-induced cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRP2 (Multi-Drug Resistance-associated Protein 2) is the cellular transporter most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis due to its role in the efflux of bile salts and bilirubin into the bile canaliculus.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that is known to have marked anticholinergic activity.
  • TCAs have high affinity for muscarinic acetylcholine (M type) receptors, causing the subsequent blockade of these receptors.
  • Blocking of these receptors can result in decreased outflow of aqueous humour, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can exacerbate pre-existing angle-closure type glaucoma, which is already characterized by impaired drainage of aqueous humour.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline is a drug to be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B and D: Sertraline and Fluvoxamine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors with no activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors and therefore have no effect on the outflow of aqueous humor and thereby, on the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor with the ability to precipitate angle-closure glaucoma by itself; however, due to lack of any activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, it does not increase the intraocular pressure to the extent that Amitriptyline does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: Maternal deaths per 1,00,000 women in the reproductive age group is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal mortality rate

 

The maternal mortality rate refers to the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age (usually between 15 and 49 years) in a given time period. This rate considers the entire population of women in the reproductive age group and not just those giving birth. It helps in assessing the risk associated with pregnancy and childbirth among all women in the reproductive age group.

 

PPH is the most common cause of Maternal mortality in India

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perinatal mortality rate: This rate measures the number of stillbirths and deaths in the first week of life per 1,000 total births. It does not specifically pertain to maternal deaths.

 

Option B. Maternal death rate: Although similar in terminology, this option is not used commonly and does not fit the precise definition provided for maternal mortality metrics.

 

Option D. Maternal mortality ratio: This ratio measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period. It specifically relates to deaths due to complications during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy but does not include the entire reproductive age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maternal mortality rate measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women in the reproductive age group, focusing on the general population of women of reproductive age rather than only those who have given birth.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used in the treatment of hemophilia B? (multiple choice) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a)  Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)
b)  Cryoprecipitate
c)  Factor VIII concentrates
d)  Cryo poor Plasma
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a & d

 

Explanation

 

Hemophilia B is a genetic bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of factor IX. The primary treatment for hemophilia B involves the replacement of the missing factor IX.

 

Treatment Options: Factor IX concentrates: The specific treatment for hemophilia B is the administration of factor IX concentrates, which directly replace the deficient clotting factor.

 

a. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP): FFP contains all the clotting factors, including factor IX, in certain proportions. It can be used as a treatment for hemophilia B, especially in situations where factor IX concentrates are not available. FFP serves as a "poor man's alternative" due to its comprehensive content of clotting factors.

 

d. Cryopoor Plasma: This is FFP from which the cryoprecipitate has been removed. While cryoprecipitate contains high levels of factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibrinogen, the cryopoor plasma retains significant amounts of factor IX. Therefore, cryopoor plasma can be used as an alternative treatment for hemophilia B. (preferred over FFP)

 

Other Options:

 

b. Cryoprecipitate: This blood product is enriched with factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibrinogen but contains little to no factor IX, making it unsuitable for treating hemophilia B.

 

c. Factor VIII concentrates: This treatment is specific to hemophilia A, which is caused by a deficiency of factor VIII. It is not effective for hemophilia B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of hemophilia B primarily involves the administration of factor IX concentrates. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) and cryopoor plasma are also viable options due to their content of factor IX. Factor VIII concentrates and cryoprecipitate are not suitable for hemophilia B as they do not contain significant levels of factor IX.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the association between the consumption of vegetarian/non-vegetarian food with certain diseases. The incidence of disease was evaluated in those two groups. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used when evaluating the association between categorical variables, such as the consumption of vegetarian or non-vegetarian food and the incidence of certain diseases. This study involves comparing the occurrence of diseases in two groups (vegetarians vs. non-vegetarians), which represents qualitative data.

 

The Chi-square test is specifically designed for non-parametric data (data that does not follow a normal distribution) and is ideal for comparing proportions, percentages, or counts between two or more groups. In this context, the test helps determine whether there is a significant association between diet type and disease occurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Paired student’s t-test: The paired student’s t-test is used for comparing means within the same group at two different times (before and after an intervention). It is suitable for continuous data, not for comparing categorical data between two distinct groups.

 

Option B. Unpaired student’s t-test: The unpaired student’s t-test compares the means of two independent groups, such as test scores or measurements. This test is used for continuous, normally distributed data and is not suitable for categorical or qualitative data like the incidence of diseases.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon test: The Wilcoxon test is a non-parametric test used for comparing two paired groups when the data is not normally distributed. It is similar to the paired t-test but for ordinal or continuous data, making it unsuitable for categorical data such as disease incidence.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chi-square test is used to determine the association between categorical variables, especially when comparing the incidence of outcomes across two or more independent groups.

choices.text: Follow up with beta-hCG
Suction and evacuation

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

 

Explanation:

 

The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.

 

Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

 

Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 614

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

 

A Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear shows many red blood cells (RBCs) infected with classic, ring-shaped and headphone-shaped trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum parasite. High degree of parasitemia and RBCs infected with two or more trophozoites were seen, a finding typical of P. falciparum malaria.

 

Cerebral malaria is a complicated form of malaria associated with multisystem organ dysfunction and high degree of morbidity and mortality. These patients often present with impaired consciousness, delirium and convulsions. It is a medical emergency where prompt diagnosis and early institution of treatment can be lifesaving. Intravenous quinine or artesunate are the mainstays of treatment in cerebral malaria.

 

Management of Cerebral Malaria:

 

  • Artesunate: Administered intravenously at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg immediately, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then once daily if necessary.
  • Alternative Treatment:
    • Artemether: 3.2 mg/kg intramuscularly initially, followed by 1.6 mg/kg once daily.
    • Quinine dihydrochloride: 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2-8 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg intravenously for 7 days: Doxycycline is not the first-line treatment for severe malaria. It is typically used as a secondary prophylactic measure or in combination with other antimalarial drugs.

 

Option B. Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days: Clindamycin is not used for the treatment of malaria. It is an antibiotic that is used for bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Chloroquine intramuscularly 8 hourly for 3 days: Chloroquine is ineffective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance. It is also not suitable for treating severe or cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

choices.text: Inside the membrane at the N-terminal end
Inside the membrane at the C-terminal end
Outside the membrane at the N-terminal end
Outside the membrane at the C-terminal end

questions.text: Where is the signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inside the membrane at the N-terminal end

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane (transmembrane region) at the N-terminal end. This is important for the proper function and orientation of the protein in the cell membrane.

 

A membrane protein can either be an integral protein (spanning the membrane) or a peripheral protein (attached to one side of the membrane).

 

Integral membrane proteins span the entire membrane and are embedded in it. They are crucial for various functions such as signaling, transport, and cell communication.

 

Peripheral proteins attach to only one surface of the membrane and do not penetrate fully.

 

Signaling sequences are short chains of amino acids located at the N-terminal end of the membrane proteins. These sequences anchor the protein to the membrane and are either cleaved or act as membrane anchors for transporting proteins across the membrane.

 

Type II integral proteins specifically have a non-cleavable N-terminal signal/anchor sequence. Examples include transferrin receptors and glycosyl transferases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inside the membrane at the C-terminal end: This option is incorrect because type II integral proteins have their signaling sequences located at the N-terminal end, not the C-terminal end.

 

Option C. Outside the membrane at the N-terminal end: This option is incorrect because signaling sequences are inside the membrane, not outside.

 

Option D. Outside the membrane at the C-terminal end: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence for type 2 proteins is located at the N-terminal end inside the membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence for a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane at the N-terminal end, which anchors the protein to the membrane.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Thyroid scan
  2. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)
  3. Thyroid function tests
  4. Ultrasound of neck
  5. Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, and 5 only

 

The clinical presentation of neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests hyperthyroidism, likely Graves' disease.

 

FNAC is not recommended in this case because it does not provide additional diagnostic yield for Graves' disease, does not alter the treatment plan, and carries a risk of complications due to the gland's increased vascularity in Graves' disease.

 

Other Options:

 

The following investigations are essential:

 

1. Thyroid scan: A radioactive iodine uptake scan helps differentiate between diffuse uptake (indicative of Graves' disease) and nodular uptake (indicative of toxic multinodular goiter or Plummer's disease).

 

3. Thyroid function tests: These are crucial as they provide information on the levels of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), helping confirm the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism.

 

4. Ultrasound of neck: This imaging modality helps assess the thyroid gland's structure and can reveal increased vascularity, which is characteristic of Graves' disease.

 

5. Anti-thyroid antibody: Testing for antibodies, such as TSH receptor antibodies (TRAbs) or thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), is important for diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases like Graves' disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with clinical signs of hyperthyroidism and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland, essential investigations include a thyroid scan, thyroid function tests, ultrasound of the neck, and anti-thyroid antibody tests. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not typically required in these cases.

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Recommended dietary allowance

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population. RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population. RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate intake: A value based on observed or experimentally determined approximations of nutrient intake by a group (or groups) of healthy people.

 

Option B. Dietary goals: are quantitative national targets for selected macronutrients and micronutrients aimed at preventing long-term chronic disease. They focus on population-level nutritional health.

 

Option C. The estimated average requirement (EAR): Average daily level of intake estimated to meet the requirements of 50% of healthy individual’s RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)

 

  • Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

questions.text:
Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Varicella zoster virus
  2. Rotavirus
  3. Measles
  4. Pneumococcal meningitis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The vaccination recommendations for the elderly typically include vaccines for Varicella Zoster Virus (to prevent shingles) and Pneumococcal meningitis (to prevent pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis).

 

  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV): The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for adults 50 years and older to prevent shingles and its complications.
  • Pneumococcal meningitis: The pneumococcal vaccines (PCV13 and PPSV23) are recommended for adults 65 years and older to protect against pneumococcal diseases, including meningitis and pneumonia.

 

Educational objective

questions.text: You are a nutritionist giving a lecture about milk pasteurization and its quality assurance tests. A curious student inquires about the various tests to validate the efficacy of pasteurization. You begin to list them, but highlight one that is not directly related to the pasteurization process. Which of the following tests does not directly evaluate the efficiency of milk pasteurization? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) lodine test 

 

  • Given tests are associated with the milk pasteurization process except for the iodine test.
  • This test is conducted to examine the potential adulteration of milk with starch or cereal flour.
  • Iodine test - The presence of addition of starch in milk can be detected using an iodine test.
  • When two or three drops of iodine solution is added to milk taken in a test tube, the solution turns dark blue.
  • This shows the presence of starch mixed with the milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatase Test: Used to check for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated by proper pasteurization. This ensures that the milk has been heated sufficiently.

 

Option C. Standard Plate Count: Measures the total bacterial count to ensure it meets the standards for pasteurized milk. A lower count indicates effective pasteurization.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue Reduction Test: Measures the time it takes for methylene blue to lose its color, which correlates with bacterial activity; high counts indicate inadequate pasteurization. This test helps verify the reduction of microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PASTEURIZATION TESTS:

 

  1. Phosphatase Test: Widely used test
  2. Standard Plate Count: Standard is coliforms be absent in 1 ml of milk
  3. Methylene blue reduction test: Enforced limit is 30,000 bacterial count per ml of pasteurized milk

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) History of diet

 

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects presents to the OPD with hematuria. His renal biopsy on light microscopy was normal. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had Gr 5 CKD and is undergoing dialysis. Which of the following would be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alport syndrome.

 

 

 

A, Alport syndrome (EM), Note the presence of both the characteristic “basket- weave” change (asterisks) and thinning of the GBM (arrows).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome is an immune-mediated disease characterised by antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of GBM type IV collagen; it is not hereditary, and light microscopy reveals extracapillary growth with crescents and necrosis.

 

Option C. IgA nephropathy: In IgA nephropathy, light microscopy would demonstrate focal mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis and mesangial widening.

 

Option D. PSGN:  In PSGN, light microscopy would reveal diffuse endocapillary proliferation with concomitant leukocytic infiltration in LM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, with characteristic findings on electron microscopy, including a "basket-weave" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane.

choices.text: High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid
Hemolytic anemia is a feature
B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate
Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.text: In folate deficiency, the False statement is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemolytic anemia is a feature

 

Folate deficiency primarily leads to megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by large, immature red blood cells (macrocytes) in the bone marrow and blood due to impaired DNA synthesis. Folate is crucial for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, the building blocks of DNA, which is why DNA synthesis is directly affected.

 

  • High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: In folate deficiency, homocysteine levels increase because folate is required for the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. However, methylmalonic acid levels remain normal, which helps differentiate folate deficiency from vitamin B12 deficiency, where methylmalonic acid levels are elevated.
  • B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is recommended because both vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies can lead to similar hematologic manifestations, like megaloblastic anemia. However, treating a patient with folic acid alone when they have an undiagnosed vitamin B12 deficiency can mask the hematologic symptoms while allowing neurological damage to progress. Therefore, it is safer to supplement both B12 and folate unless B12 deficiency has been ruled out.
  • Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: Folate is essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, which are necessary for DNA replication. Specifically, folate is involved in the transfer of one-carbon units during the synthesis of these nucleotides. In its absence, DNA synthesis is impaired, leading to megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: This statement is true and correctly describes the biochemical changes in folate deficiency.

 

Option C. B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is a true statement and an important clinical practice to avoid masking B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: This statement is true because folate is directly involved in nucleotide synthesis, which is critical for DNA replication and repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia. It is associated with high homocysteine levels and normal methylmalonic acid levels, and folate is essential for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, which are necessary for DNA synthesis

questions.text: For which medical condition is the provided drug typically recommended? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Malaria

 

The picture depicts artemisin-based combination therapy (ACT). This medicine is used to treat falciparum malaria.

 

ARTEMISINS - Artesunate and Artemether

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

Artemisin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), is typically recommended for the treatment of falciparum malaria.

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife is tasked with organizing a vaccination camp within a rural community. She has been provided with 2 vials that have been unsealed. Among these, one contains a pentavalent vaccine, while the other holds an MR vaccine. What options does she have in terms of effectively using these vials? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

 

According to the Open Vial Policy, certain vaccines can be used for subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks after opening, provided they have been stored properly and are not expired. This policy helps to minimize vaccine wastage and ensure efficient use of available vaccines.

 

Open Vial Policy (2015)

 

  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session ‘UPTO 4 WEEKS’
  • Open vial policy – 
    • Applicable for - Hep B, OPV, DPT, Liquid pentavalent, TT, PCV, IPV, HiB
    • Not applicable for - BCG, MR, JE, RVV, Covid-19 vaccines
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Under the Open Vial Policy, the auxiliary nurse midwife can use the pentavalent vaccine for subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks after opening, but must discard the MR vaccine as it does not fall under the Open Vial Policy.

choices.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Isolate for 6 days

 

The given scenario points to the diagnosis of chickenpox.

 

In a boys' hostel, everyone is not in the high-risk groups for severe varicella infection. For the management of suspected cases in this situation, isolation for 6 days from the onset of the rash is the appropriate measure to prevent further spread of the infection. Acyclovir and ZIG are not necessary for healthy individuals.

 

Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is indicated as prophylaxis for individuals at high risk like Immunocompromised individuals, Pregnant women and Newborns.

 

 

 

Note –

 

Acyclovir: Antiviral treatment with acyclovir is generally reserved for high-risk groups or severe cases.

 

VZIG (Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin): VZIG is indicated for individuals at high risk of severe varicella infection, such as immunocompromised individuals, pregnant women, and newborns. It is not routinely given to healthy individuals in a setting like a boys' hostel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For managing a chickenpox outbreak in a boys' hostel, the best step is to isolate affected individuals for 6 days from the onset of the rash. This helps prevent the spread of the virus. Antiviral treatments and immunoglobulins are reserved for high-risk individuals.

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

questions.text:
HDI is calculated by using ? [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Life expectancy at birth
  2. Mean years of schooling
  3. Gross national product
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) All three


The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite index used to measure the overall achievement of a country in three basic dimensions of human development:

 

  1. Health: Measured by life expectancy at birth, which reflects the average number of years a newborn is expected to live if current mortality rates continue to apply.
  2. Education: Measured by the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or older and expected years of schooling for children entering school. This represent knowledge, enrolment ratio.
  3. Living Standards: Measured by Gross National Income (GNI) per capita, expressed in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP) in US dollars.

 

These components together provide a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development, allowing for comparisons across countries.

 

Educational Objective:
 

HDI is calculated using three components: life expectancy at birth, mean years of schooling, and Gross National Income per capita. These factors represent health, education, and living standards, respectively.

 

  • HDI range – 0 to +1
  • HDI (India) – 0.644 (Rank 134)
  • HDI (Switzerland) – 0.96 (Rank 1)

questions.text: Components of Disaster cycle that can be included in the recovery phase are: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction

 

 

The disaster cycle consists of several phases: impact, response, rehabilitation, reconstruction, mitigation, and preparedness.

 

The recovery phase specifically focuses on restoring the affected area to normalcy and includes three key components: Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction (Mnemonic: 3Rs). These steps are crucial for rebuilding after a disaster, addressing immediate needs (response), restoring essential services (rehabilitation), and rebuilding infrastructure (reconstruction).

 

Educational Objective:
 

The recovery phase of the disaster cycle includes the components of Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction, which are essential for restoring the community post-disaster.

choices.text: Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology
IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control
DC Cardioversion is required in all cases
Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man collapsed and was brought to the emergency. ECG was taken and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) was made. Which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control

 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves on ECG, which confirms the diagnosis. Each of the provided options needs to be evaluated for accuracy.

 

IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control. This is the correct statement. IV Digoxin is used for rate control in AF, particularly in patients with heart failure.

 

If the patient is stable and not in acute heart failure, beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem are preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology: This statement is incorrect. Atrial fibrillation can occur in morphologically normal hearts. Studies indicate that 15-35% of AF cases can be seen in individuals with structurally normal hearts, although it is more common in those with conditions such as heart failure or left atrial enlargement.

 

Option C. DC Cardioversion is required in all cases: This statement is incorrect. DC cardioversion is reserved for unstable patients or for rhythm control in selected chronic cases. It is not required for all AF cases.

 

Option D. Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a pulse deficit (difference between heart rate and pulse rate) can suggest AF, it is not a reliable diagnostic criterion as it can be observed in other conditions such as frequent ventricular premature contractions, cardiac tamponade, and severe heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV Digoxin can be effectively used for ventricular rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in those with heart failure.

choices.text: By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

questions.text: The adjoining graph shows the effect of PTH on blood calcium and phosphate in an experimental animal. How does PTH increase plasma calcium? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

 

Explanation:

 

PTH increases calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing the kidneys' excretion of calcium, effectively increasing plasma calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By increasing osteoclast activity: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates osteoclasts indirectly, leading to increased bone resorption, which releases calcium into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. By increasing osteoblastic activity: While PTH does stimulate osteoblasts, this action is primarily to produce RANKL, a cytokine that activates osteoclasts, not to build new bone.

 

Option C. By decreasing renal excretion: PTH reduces calcium excretion by the kidneys, increasing reabsorption of calcium in the renal tubules, contributing to higher blood calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases plasma calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing renal excretion of calcium.

choices.text: HLA B27 is associated in 90% cases
It is non-erosive and only joints are affected
Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign
Affects males more than females

questions.text: All are true about Ankylosing spondylitis except:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is non-erosive and only joints are affected

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by erosive changes.  
  • AS is not completely non-erosive.
  • Over time, inflammation can lead to erosive changes, especially in the sacroiliac joints and the spine.
  • The inflammatory process in AS often leads to erosion of the vertebrae and the formation of syndesmophyte (bone spurs), which contribute to the fusion of spinal segments.
  • While AS primarily affects the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), it can also involve other structures.
  • Extra-articular manifestations can include enthesitis (inflammation of the sites where tendons and ligaments attach to bone), uveitis (eye inflammation), and in some cases, systemic symptoms like fatigue and anemia.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HLA-B27 is associated in 90% of cases: HLA-B27 is a genetic marker that is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Approximately 90% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis test positive for the HLA-B27 antigen. However, not all individuals with this antigen will develop the disease, and not all AS patients will test positive for HLA-B27. The exact role of HLA-B27 in the pathogenesis of AS is not fully understood, but it is considered a significant genetic risk factor. HLA-B27 positivity is used as part of the diagnostic process and can help in predicting the likelihood of AS in patients with symptoms.

 

Option C. Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign: Sacroiliac joint involvement is often one of the earliest signs of ankylosing spondylitis. The sacroiliac joints are typically among the first to be affected in AS. Early symptoms include lower back pain and stiffness that improves with activity and worsens with rest. X-rays or MRI of the sacroiliac joints can reveal characteristic changes associated with AS, such as sacroiliitis (inflammation of the sacroiliac joints) and eventually, structural changes such as joint fusion.

 

 

Option D. Affects males more than females: Ankylosing spondylitis is more common in males than females. Studies suggest that the male-to-female ratio for AS is approximately 2:1 to 3:1. The disease may present differently in women, sometimes leading to a delay in diagnosis. Women with AS might have a less pronounced spinal involvement and more peripheral joint symptoms compared to men.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is an erosive inflammatory condition in which axial skeleton particularly in the spine and sacroiliac joints and other organs are affected.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered the most sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community. IMR reflects the overall health and well-being of infants and the quality of maternal and infant care services. It is a comprehensive measure that can indicate various aspects of public health, including nutritional status, access to medical care, public health practices, and the socio-economic conditions of the community.

 

IMR = (Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births) × 1000.

 

SRS 2022-23 Latest data

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in Static Two-point discrimination? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Merkel disk

 

Static two-point discrimination requires a receptor that adapts very slowly to maintain sensation over a prolonged period. Merkel cells are crucial for this function.

 

Merkel cells:

 

  • They are slow-adapting receptors
  • Excellent for 2-point discrimination
  • Have a less receptive field
  • Critical for detecting edges and points
  • Particularly important for tasks like Braille reading

 

The key characteristics that make Merkel cells ideal for static two-point discrimination are:

 

  1. Slow adaptation rate
  2. Ability to detect steady stimuli
  3. Precise localization of sensory input

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Meissner's corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors, making them unsuitable for static discrimination. They are best for fine touch sensations.

 

Option C. Pacinian corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors present at Deep dermis, joint capsule that sense high-frequency vibration and pressure, not static stimuli.

 

Option D. Ruffini ending: Incorrect. While these are slow-adapting mechanoreceptors, they primarily sense stretch and sustained pressure, not precise point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • Management includes
  • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy: Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.

 

Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction: Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.

 

Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe: Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.

 

Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Match the following anesthetic agents with respect to their side effects. 

 

Column A:

1. Propofol

2. Fentanyl

3. Midazolam

4. Nitrous oxide

 

Column B:

a. Rigid chest syndrome

b. Pulmonary vasoconstriction

c. Egg allergy

d. Hypotension
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 → c, 2 → a, 3 → d, 4 → b

 

  1. Propofol → Egg allergy (c): Propofol is a lipid-soluble anesthetic agent that is formulated with soybean oil, glycerol, and egg phospholipids. Due to the inclusion of egg components, there is a potential risk of allergic reactions, particularly in patients with a known egg allergy.
  2. Fentanyl → Rigid chest syndrome (a): Fentanyl is a potent opioid analgesic that can cause severe muscle rigidity, particularly in the chest wall, which is known as rigid chest syndrome. This side effect is significant because it can make ventilation difficult during anesthesia.
  3. Midazolam → Hypotension (d): Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that induces sedation and vasodilatation, which may lead to a decrease in blood pressure, causing hypotension. This effect is dose-dependent and more pronounced in patients with pre-existing cardiovascular issues.
  4. Nitrous oxide → Pulmonary vasoconstriction (b): Nitrous oxide is known to cause pulmonary vasoconstriction, which can increase pulmonary vascular resistance. This effect may be problematic in patients with pre-existing pulmonary hypertension or cardiovascular conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Propofol: Risk of egg allergy due to its lipid formulation.
  • Fentanyl: Can cause rigid chest syndrome, making ventilation difficult.
  • Midazolam: May lead to hypotension through vasodilatation.
  • Nitrous oxide: Can cause pulmonary vasoconstriction, increasing pulmonary vascular resistance.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td vaccine

 

In the national immunization schedule, the TT/Td vaccine is given to children at 10 years & 16 years of age as part of the school immunization program.

 

Additional Information

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles Vaccine can be given till 5 years of age.

 

Option B. Rotavirus vaccines can be given till 12 years of age.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccine can be given till 1 year of age.

National Immunisation schedule (2023-24):

choices.text: MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to your hospital emergency with pregnancy 22 weeks, which was a result of rape. Correct statement regarding Medical Termination of Pregnancy is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks of pregnancy. For gestation periods from 0 to 20 weeks, it is considered low risk and only one doctor’s opinion is required.

 

However, for gestation periods from 20 to 24 weeks, it is categorized as high risk, and the approval of two doctors is required. This high-risk category includes specific situations such as rape, incest, disability, and when the woman is a minor. Since the woman in the question is 22 weeks pregnant due to rape, MTP is permissible under these regulations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG: This is incorrect because MTP after 24 weeks is not routinely allowed. It requires a medical board's approval and is only permitted in exceptional cases involving severe fetal anomalies or conditions that endanger the mother’s life.

 

Option C. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother: This statement is incorrect. For 20-24 weeks POG, MTP is permitted not only for life-threatening conditions but also for cases involving rape, incest, disability, and minors.

 

Option D. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only: This is incorrect because two doctors' opinions are required for high-risk cases between 20-24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks of pregnancy is considered high risk and requires two doctors' opinions, especially in cases of rape, incest, disability, or if the woman is a minor.

questions.text:
To study the effect of Vitamin C consumption on the occurrence of Respiratory disease, arrange the steps of a case-control study in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]


1 – Measurement of exposure.
2 – Matching.
3 – Analysis and interpretation.
4 – Selection of cases and controls.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4-2-1-3

 
A case-control study is a retrospective observational study design commonly used to investigate the causes of a condition or disease. The steps are as follows:

 

4. Selection of cases and controls : The first step involves identifying the cases (individuals with the disease) and controls (individuals without the disease). In this example, cases would be people with respiratory disease, and controls would be those without it.

 

2. Matching : The next step is to match the cases and controls on various confounding factors such as age, gender, or lifestyle to minimize bias.

 

1. Measurement of exposure : After matching, the history of exposure to the risk factor (in this case, Vitamin C consumption) is measured for both cases and controls by collecting historical data.

 

3. Analysis and interpretation : Finally, data is analyzed, often using a 2x2 table to calculate the odds ratio, which determines the association between the exposure and the disease. An odds ratio greater than 1 indicates a positive association, less than 1 indicates a protective effect, and equal to 1 indicates no association.

 

Educational Objective:


The correct sequence of steps in a case-control study is: Selection of cases and controls, matching, measurement of exposure, and then analysis and interpretation.

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination the BMI was 43 kg/m² and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? PaO2: 70 mmHg PaCO2: 53 mmHg HCO3: 33 mmHg. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), also known as Pickwickian syndrome, is characterized by obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), hypoventilation (PaCO2 >45 mmHg), and lack of significant underlying lung disease. The ABG findings showing hypercapnia (high PaCO2) and hypoxemia (low PaO2) in the awake state are indicative of OHS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive sleep apnea: Occurs during sleep, not necessarily presenting with hypercapnia in the awake state.
 

Option C. Central sleep apnea: Characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep without the obesity-related hypoventilation.
 

Option D. Narcolepsy: Does not typically present with ABG abnormalities or obesity hypoventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome involves obesity, chronic hypercapnia, and hypoxemia, primarily in the awake state.

questions.text: In a clinical study exploring the relationship between variables X and Y, a scatter plot with a linear regression line has been generated. Based on the graphical representation provided, which of the following equations corresponds to the linear regression model of the plotted graph? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) y=11+2x

 

  • Y = 11 + 2x is a simple linear regression equation where a = 11 and b = 2 are constants and x and y are variables.
  • Regression is change in measurements of a variable. It provides structure of relationship between 2 quantitative variables.

 

Types of regressions:

 

  • Simple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable
  • Multiple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variable
  • Simple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable, with some power of independent variable
  • Multiple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variables, with some power of independent variables).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of regression equations:

choices.text: Transition from infectious pandemic diseases to man-made diseases
Transition from low literacy levels to high literacy levels
Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate
Transition from unfavorable sex ratio to favorable sex ratio

questions.text: What is demographic transition as a country passes through the demographic cycle? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate

 

 

The demographic transition refers to the shift in a country’s population characteristics as it moves through different stages of the demographic cycle. The cycle typically includes five stages, starting with high birth and death rates (Stage 1), followed by declining death rates (Stage 2), declining birth rates (Stage 3), and eventually both low birth and death rates (Stage 4). This process reflects changes in a society’s economic and social conditions, such as improvements in healthcare, education, and overall living standards. The transition leads to slower population growth and ultimately stabilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition from infectious pandemic diseases to man-made diseases: This option describes the epidemiological transition, which refers to the shift in the types of prevalent diseases from infectious to chronic, non-communicable diseases as a society develops.

 

Option B. Transition from low literacy levels to high literacy levels: This option reflects educational and social changes within a population but does not specifically describe demographic transition.

 

Option D. Transition from unfavorable sex ratio to favorable sex ratio: This option describes changes in gender ratios, often due to social or policy influences, but it is not directly related to demographic transition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demographic transition is characterized by the shift from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country progresses through the stages of the demographic cycle.

questions.text: What type of connective tissue is found in the region indicated by the black arrow in the provided image? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dense irregular

 

In the provided image, the black arrow points to a region with a meshwork of collagen fibers. This pattern is characteristic of dense irregular connective tissue, which is identified by its densely packed collagen fibers that are arranged in an irregular, haphazard fashion. This type of connective tissue provides strength and support and allows the skin to resist multidirectional forces. It is typically found in areas that require strength and rigidity, such as the dermis of the skin, which is what is likely being shown in this histological slide.

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue.

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dense regular connective tissue features collagen fibers that are parallel to each other, conferring tensile strength in one particular direction. It is typically found in tendons and ligaments, where the force is exerted in a single direction as shown in the image below.

 

 

This is not what we see in the image, where the fibers are not arranged in parallel.

 

Irregular and Regular connective tissue

 

 

Option C. Loose regular connective tissue is not a recognized classification.

 

Option D. Loose irregular connective tissue is also not a recognized classification. What is commonly known is loose connective tissue (also termed areolar connective tissue), which has a much looser fiber arrangement and a lot of ground substance, often found beneath epithelial layers, surrounding blood vessels, and nerves. It has a different appearance from what is indicated by the arrow in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image shows dense irregular connective tissue, which is characterized by a dense network of collagen fibers arranged in an irregular pattern, commonly found in the dermis of the skin, providing strength and the ability to resist multi-directional forces.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the internal capsule?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Charcot's artery supplies the posterior limb.
  2. Retrolenticular part of the internal capsule contains optic radiation.
  3. Anterior limb of the capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers of the upper limb and face.
  4. Internal capsule has projection fibers.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The internal capsule is primarily composed of projection fibers that connect the cortex to other parts of the brain or spinal cord. The internal capsule can be divided into three parts: anterior limb, genu, and posterior limb. Lesions in these areas can result in different neurological deficits.

 

  • The anterior limb contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the thalamus and basal ganglia, and lesions here can cause motor and behavioral changes. Fronto pontine fibers also pass via anterior limb.
  • The genu contains fibers that connect the frontal cortex to the contralateral motor cortex, and lesions here can cause facial weakness and hemiparesis. Fronto pontine and cortico nuclear fibers pass via genu.
  • The posterior limb contains fibers that connect the sensory and motor cortices to the brainstem and spinal cord, and lesions here can cause sensory and motor deficits Fronto pontine, cortico spinal fir trunk, upper as well as lower limbs via posterior limb..

 

The retrolenticular part of the internal capsule carries fibers primarily from the optic radiation, which is a bundle of axons that originate from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and terminate in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Lesions in this area can result in visual field deficits, such as homonymous hemianopia, superior or inferior quadrantanopia. (Parieto pontine and occipito pontine fibers also pass via retrolentiform) Charcots artery supplies the genu and posterior limb. Hence statement 1, 2 and 4 correct.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 4: Internal capsule has projection fibers - The internal capsule contains a large collection of projection fibers that include both ascending sensory and descending motor pathways. These fibers connect the cerebral cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord, conveying sensory information to the cortex and motor commands away from the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule, a key white matter structure in the brain, contains Charcot's artery-supplied posterior limb, optic radiation in the retrolenticular part, and is primarily composed of projection fibers linking the cortex with the brainstem and spinal cord. Misinformation about the anterior limb's contents highlights the complexity and specificity of its neural pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoglycemia


Salbutamol, a β2-adrenergic agonist, is commonly used as a bronchodilator to treat conditions like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It has several known side effects, but hypoglycemia is not one of them. In fact, salbutamol can cause hyperglycemia as a result of increased glycogenolysis in the liver and reduced insulin sensitivity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Mechanism: Salbutamol stimulates β2 receptors in various tissues:

 

Option A. Tachycardia: Tachycardia is a well-documented adverse effect of salbutamol. The drug can cause increased heart rate through reflex sympathetic stimulation and a direct impact on cardiac β1 receptors.

 

Option B. Tolerance: Tolerance can develop with long-term use of salbutamol, as the body becomes desensitized to the drug's effects due to receptor downregulation.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: Salbutamol causes hypokalemia by promoting the uptake of potassium into cells, particularly in the skeletal muscles, thus lowering plasma potassium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salbutamol's adverse effects include tachycardia, hypokalemia, and the development of tolerance with prolonged use. It does not cause hypoglycemia but rather can lead to hyperglycemia.

questions.text: What is the stage of sleep denoted by the arrow: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

Explanation:

 

The stage of sleep indicated by the arrow is REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This can be identified based on the specific patterns observed in the EEG (Electroencephalogram), EMG (Electromyogram), and EOG (Electrooculogram) readings:

 

 

 

  • EEG: The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves.
  • EMG: The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams.
  • EOG: The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.

 

In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep stages (including NREM 2, 3, and 4) show different patterns:

 

  • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns.
  • Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep.
  • Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NREM 2: This stage of sleep is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG, with reduced but not absent muscle tone and minimal eye movement. The patterns described in the question do not match this stage.

 

Option B. NREM 3: Known as slow-wave sleep or deep sleep, NREM 3 is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. Muscle tone is decreased but not completely absent, and there is minimal to no eye movement. The pattern described does not correspond to NREM 3.

 

Option C. NREM 4: Often combined with NREM 3 in the modern classification, this stage is also characterized by delta waves, reduced muscle tone, and lack of eye movement. The described pattern is inconsistent with this stage as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, high-frequency EEG waves, muscle atonia as shown in the EMG, and rapid eye movements as shown in the EOG. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for correctly identifying REM sleep, which is a critical stage for processes like memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

  • House-Shaped Hand: The hand shaped like a house emphasizes that the cured individual is an integral part of their family and community.

 

These elements collectively reinforce the message of hope, inclusion, and the need to remove stigma associated with leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrated Disease Surveillance Program (logo):

 

 

Option B.  National TB Elimination Program (logo):

 

 

Option D.  National Health Mission (logo):

 

 

Educational Objective:


The National Leprosy Eradication Program logo symbolizes hope, the curability of leprosy, and the inclusion of cured individuals into society, promoting a stigma-free approach towards the disease.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Out of the options given below, what is the cause of death in smoke inhalation? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anemic hypoxia

 

Smoke contains multiple substances, of which the most significant component is carbon monoxide (CO). CO can cause both anemic hypoxia as well as histotoxic hypoxia, but predominant cause is anemic hypoxia. Mechanism of hypoxia by CO:

 

  • Anemic Hypoxia by CO: CO combines with hb to form COHb) producing anemic hypoxia (blood O2-carrying capacity is reduced)
  • Histotoxic Hypoxia by CO: While the primary impact of CO is on blood oxygen transport, the presence of COHb can also interfere with cellular respiration at the tissue level. COHb affects mitochondrial function and the electron transport chain, disrupting the cells' ability to utilize the oxygen that is delivered to them.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when cells can’t effectively use the available oxygen

due to interference with crucial cellular processes. CO causes histotoxic hypoxia also but the main cause of death is anemic hypoxia. A typical example of histotoxic hypoxia is cyanide poisoning.

 

Option B) Ischemic hypoxia results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock.

 

Option D) All of the above it is incorrect as CO may cause anemic and histotoxic hypoxia but not ischemic hypoxia

 

Educational objective

 

Anemic hypoxia

 

  • Anemic hypoxia is hypoxia  caused by the decreased O2-carrying capacity of blood. It can occur due to two reasons:
    • Hb concentration is low, or
    • Hb concentration may be normal, but it is not able to bind to O2. It can occur due to following conditions:
      • CO Poisoning: It has a higher affinity for Hb than O2 forming COHb.
      • Methemoglobinemia: Methemoglobin is a form of Hb where the iron is in the ferric state (Fe3+) instead of the normal ferrous state (Fe2+). Methemoglobin cannot bind to oxygen effectively.
      • Certain Genetic Hemoglobin Disorders altering the structure of Hb, e.g.

Sickle cell anemia, thalassemia.

questions.text: Phospholipase C acts via which of the following G protein-coupled receptors?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gq 

 

Phospholipase C acts via the Gq type of G protein-coupled receptors. It leads to the activation of the IP3-DAG pathway. The receptors that act via this pathway include the receptors of H1, α1, M1, V1, M3, Angiotensin II, Gastrin, GnRH, Oxytocin and TRH.


Important points about GPCR:

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times (heptahelical). Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go. GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

 

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and thus increase in cAMP.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and thus decrease in cAMP.
  • Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C which generates the second messengers inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). It helps in mobilizing Ca2+ form the endoplasmic reticulum stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, which in turn generate the second messengers IP3 and DAG, leading to various downstream effects, including the mobilization of calcium ions from intracellular stores.
