40 weeks

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The management of anticoagulation in pregnant women with cardiac disease involves switching from warfarin to heparin at specific times to minimize the risk of complications to the fetus and to prepare for delivery.

 

  • Switch to Heparin at 36 Weeks: According to guidelines from the American College of Chest Physicians, pregnant women on warfarin therapy should switch to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation. This is done to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

 

Guidelines Summary:

 

  1. Early Pregnancy (up to 12 weeks):
    • Discontinue warfarin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed, especially if the warfarin dose is >5mg/day, due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy.
    • Replace with heparin (5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).
  2. After 12 Weeks to 36 Weeks:
    • Warfarin can be resumed after the 12th week and continued up to 36 weeks.
  3. At 36 Weeks:
    • Switch from warfarin to heparin (either unfractionated or LMWH).
  4. Just Before Delivery:
    • Discontinue heparin just before delivery.
  5. Postpartum:
    • Restart heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after cesarean section.
    • Warfarin therapy can also be safely resumed during breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The final switch from warfarin to heparin in pregnant women with cardiac disease is advised at 36 weeks of gestation to minimize the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Setting up cobalt therapy units

 

The Colombo Plan, established in 1950, was drawn up for the cooperative economic development of South and South-East Asia. It included 20 countries with the main aim of improving the living standards of people. The plan focused on industrial and agricultural development and provided support for health promotion, mostly through fellowships.

 

Key Contributions of the Colombo Plan:

 

  • AIIMS, New Delhi: Established with financial assistance from New Zealand.
  • Cobalt Therapy Units: Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India as part of the Colombo Plan. These units significantly enhanced the capabilities for cancer treatment in India.

 

Cobalt Therapy Units:

 

  • Cobalt Therapy: Involves using gamma rays from cobalt-60 isotopes to treat cancer. It was a crucial development in radiotherapy in the mid-20th century and improved cancer treatment outcomes significantly.
  • Provision under Colombo Plan: The supply of cobalt therapy units by Canada helped Indian medical institutions upgrade their cancer treatment facilities, making advanced radiotherapy accessible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Colombo Plan, Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India, significantly enhancing the country's capacity to provide advanced cancer treatment through radiotherapy. This was a crucial step in improving healthcare infrastructure and cancer treatment capabilities in India.

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination, especially during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to follow proper procedures to avoid contamination and ensure the sample's accuracy. The best practice is to collect water from a gentle stream to avoid splashing, which can introduce contaminants from the environment into the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect water from already leaking tape: Not recommended as it could contaminate the sample and may lead to false results.

 

Option B. Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 2 minutes

 

Option C. Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: It is a good practice but this practice alone does not ensure the proper collection of the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: Arrange the steps of the Disaster cycle in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation  

 

The disaster cycle outlines the sequential steps taken in response to a disaster and how communities can prepare and recover from such events. The correct sequence is:

 

  1. Disaster Impact: This is the immediate occurrence of the disaster event, such as an earthquake, flood, or hurricane, leading to direct damage and disruption.
  2. Response: Following the impact, emergency measures are taken to save lives, provide first aid, conduct search and rescue, and offer immediate relief such as food, shelter, and medical treatment.
  3. Rehabilitation: After the initial response, efforts shift to restoring essential services and helping affected communities return to normal. This involves rebuilding infrastructure, ensuring public health, and restoring social and economic activities.
  4. Mitigation: This final step involves implementing measures to reduce the severity of future disasters. This can include building stronger infrastructure, improving disaster preparedness plans, and promoting community awareness to minimize potential damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the disaster cycle is: Disaster Impact → Response → Rehabilitation → Mitigation.

questions.text: Which of the following transport mechanism doesn’t require ATP: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

The image shows four different transport mechanisms across cell membranes:

 

1. Simple diffusion through membrane: This shows direct diffusion of molecules through the lipid bilayer from high concentration to low concentration. This is also passive transport that doesn't require ATP.

 

2. Simple diffusion through channels: This shows molecules moving through a protein channel from high concentration to low concentration. This is passive transport that follows the concentration gradient without requiring ATP. Channels have gates that simply open or close without configurational changes, allowing molecules to pass according to their concentration gradient.

 

3. Paracellular transport: This shows molecules moving between cells through the spaces between adjacent cells, not through the cells themselves. This is passive movement along the concentration gradient and doesn't require ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Active transport: This shows fewer molecules on one side and more on the other side, indicating movement against the concentration gradient (from low to high concentration). This requires energy in the form of ATP to power the transport proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple diffusion through membrane, Simple diffusion through channels, Paracellular transport do not require ATP as they represent forms of passive transport, while Active transport requiring ATP

choices.text: Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

questions.text: Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell injury? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

 

The most important light microscopic features of irreversible cell injury are nuclear changes. These changes are indicative of cell death and include:

 

  • Pyknosis: The nucleus shrinks and becomes dense, with chromatin condensing into a solid, darkly staining mass.
  • Karyorrhexis: The pyknotic nucleus fragments into smaller pieces.
  • Karyolysis: The nuclear fragments dissolve and fade, leading to the eventual loss of the nucleus.

 

These nuclear changes are hallmark signs of irreversible cell damage and cell death, distinguishing them from reversible changes such as cellular swelling or detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amorphous densities in mitochondria: These changes are often seen in irreversible cell injury, particularly in the context of mitochondrial dysfunction, but nuclear changes are more definitive indicators of irreversible damage.

 

Option B. Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli: These features are associated with reversible cell injury, not irreversible injury. They indicate cellular swelling and loss of structural integrity but do not signify cell death.

 

Option C. Ribosomal detachment from endoplasmic reticulum: This is also a feature of reversible cell injury, indicating disruption in protein synthesis, but it does not define irreversible injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis on light microscopy are signs of irreversible cell injury.

questions.text: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the Infant was 60 mg/dl. Which other investigation would you do? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum calcium

 

In infants born to diabetic mothers, it is essential to assess the serum calcium level to rule out hypocalcemia. Infants of diabetic mothers are predisposed to conditions like hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

 

  • Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium level below 8 mg/dL in term infants and below 7 mg/dL in preterm infants. This condition often occurs due to lower levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in infants of diabetic mothers. In utero, the higher levels of maternal serum ionized calcium may suppress the fetal parathyroid glands, leading to hypocalcemia after birth. If untreated, hypocalcemia can result in neurological symptoms, including seizures, headaches, and neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium: Serum potassium is not directly related to hypoglycemia in infants of diabetic mothers. The primary concern in this scenario is hypocalcemia rather than potassium imbalance.

 

Option B. CBC: While a complete blood count (CBC) can provide useful information, it is not specifically related to the metabolic risks associated with infants of diabetic mothers. Serum calcium is a more appropriate investigation in this context.

 

Option C. Serum chloride: Serum chloride levels do not have a direct connection with hypoglycemia or the other metabolic issues typically seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Therefore, it is not the most relevant test in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In infants of diabetic mothers, it is crucial to monitor serum calcium levels alongside blood glucose to detect and manage hypocalcemia, which can have significant neurological implications if untreated.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness. The resting pulse was 110 beats per minute. Which of the following tests should be done next to evaluate her condition further? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TSH

 

Explanation:

 

In the evaluation of suspected thyroid dysfunction, the initial and most crucial test is the measurement of Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH). TSH is the most sensitive indicator of thyroid function because even minor changes in thyroid hormone levels cause significant changes in TSH levels due to the feedback mechanism between the thyroid gland and the pituitary gland. Elevated or suppressed TSH levels provide clear insight into whether the thyroid gland is underactive (hypothyroidism) or overactive (hyperthyroidism). Given the patient's symptoms of weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness, hyperthyroidism is suspected, making TSH the appropriate initial test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Total T3: T3 levels can be influenced by various factors and are usually measured after initial TSH and Free T4 tests suggest hyperthyroidism.

 

Option B.  Thyroid Scan: This imaging test evaluates thyroid structure and function, useful in cases where nodules or hyperactivity need to be assessed. It is not the first-line test for evaluating general thyroid function.

 

Option C. Free T4: Free T4 is important in assessing thyroid function and is typically measured alongside TSH. However, TSH is preferred as the initial screening test due to its sensitivity in detecting thyroid dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial test for evaluating suspected thyroid dysfunction, particularly in hyperthyroid symptoms, is TSH due to its sensitivity and reliability in reflecting thyroid status.

An additional 41 deaths occurred during 8-28 days of life. Calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality rate for the given community. [NEET PG 2024]

ENMR formula:

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is calculated as the number of early neonatal deaths (0-7 days) per 1,000 live births.

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

 

Explanation:

 

This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.

 

Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.2 Hz: This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option B. 2 Hz: This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. 20 Hz: This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pediatric controlled ventilation

 

Jackson Rees circuit (also known as Mapleson F circuit) is specifically designed for:

 

  • Pediatric patients
  • Can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation in children
  • It's a modification of the Ayre's T-piece with an open-ended bag
  • This circuit is ideal for pediatric anesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Adult controlled ventilation: Not appropriate as Jackson Rees circuit is designed for pediatric patients. Adults require circuits with larger volumes and different configurations.

 

Option C. Obstetric ventilation: Obstetric patients require specialized circuits that can deliver high flow rates and manage rapid changes in ventilation demands.

 

Option D. Cardiac patients: Cardiac patients typically require precise control over ventilation parameters, which is better achieved with more sophisticated circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is specifically designed and used for pediatric anesthesia, suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment-effacement lesion in the intestinal mucosa? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli


Attaching-and-effacing is the “hallmark” of the EPEC infections, a lesion that is characterized by the intimate attachment of the bacteria to the host epithelial cell membrane and the effacement of the microvilli. This mechanism is a hallmark of EPEC infections, leading to copious watery diarrhea, especially in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): Incorrect: ETEC causes watery diarrhea through the production of enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) or cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC): Incorrect: EIEC invades and destroys epithelial cells lining the colon, leading to fever, cramping, watery diarrhea, and dysentery with scant, bloody stools. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option D. Diffusely adherent Escherichia coli (DAEC): Incorrect: DAEC is known for its diffuse adherence pattern to epithelial cells, causing persistent diarrhea in children. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which disease is represented by the submerged portion of the iceberg in the iceberg model? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Influenza

 

The iceberg model represents diseases that have a visible portion (the tip) and a hidden portion (submerged part). The tip of the iceberg represents clinical cases that are easily diagnosed by healthcare providers, typically through visible symptoms. The submerged portion, which is much larger, represents the hidden cases, including asymptomatic, subclinical, latent, and pre-symptomatic individuals who still carry the disease but are not easily visible to healthcare providers.

 

Influenza exhibits the iceberg phenomenon because many individuals with the virus remain undiagnosed as they show mild or no symptoms. These hidden cases contribute significantly to the spread of the disease as these individuals do not seek medical attention and thus remain below the surface of clinical observation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Tetanus does not exhibit the iceberg phenomenon because it does not have carriers or asymptomatic cases. The disease only manifests as clinical cases, which are visible to healthcare providers.

 

Option B. Measles: Measles does not have an iceberg phenomenon due to the absence of carriers and asymptomatic cases. It is typically a visible disease with noticeable symptoms once infection occurs.

 

Option C. Rubella: Similar to measles, rubella also does not have an iceberg phenomenon as it does not involve carriers or hidden cases. The infection is primarily identified through its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iceberg phenomenon describes diseases with a significant proportion of hidden, asymptomatic, or subclinical cases, such as influenza, which contribute to disease transmission.

 

Remember – No carriers – No iceberg Phenomena – Measles, Rubella, Rabies, Tetanus and + Pertussis

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Age < 1 year
  2. Temperature of 38-39°C
  3. Duration of fever < 24 h
  4. Duration of fever > 48 h
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children who are less than 1 year old, have a fever with a temperature between 38-39°C, and have a fever duration of less than 24 hours. Febrile seizures typically occur in children between the ages of 6 and 60 months and are generalized tonic-clonic seizures that occur in the setting of fever without any underlying intracranial infection or a previous history of unprovoked seizures.

 

Risk Factors:

 

1. Age < 1 year: Younger age increases the likelihood of recurrent febrile seizures.

 

2. Temperature of 38-39°C: Lower fever temperatures (38-39°C) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

3. Duration of fever < 24 h: A shorter duration of fever before the onset of seizures is associated with an increased risk of recurrence.

 

Other Information:

 

  • Minor risk factors for recurrence include male gender, attending daycare, having complex febrile seizures, a family history of febrile seizures, and lower serum sodium levels at presentation.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Duration of fever > 48 hours: A duration of fever greater than 48 hours is not considered a risk factor for febrile seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of recurrent febrile seizures is increased in children under 1 year of age, with fever temperatures between 38-39°C, and fever lasting less than 24 hours.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition. [NEET PG  2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

 

Given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of neurolathyrism, for which the toxin responsible is beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA).

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings
  • Osteolathyrism: In animals

 

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Lathyrism affects 15 - 45 years of age

 

  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)’Q
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of Lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aflatoxin: Toxin produced by Aspergillus species. It causes aflatoxicosis and is commonly found in contaminated ground nuts.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Toxins produced by Claviceps species, leading to ergotism. Found in contaminated cereals.

 

Option D. Fusarium toxin: Toxins produced by Fusarium species, which can contaminate grains and other food products, causing fusarium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

 

The patient presents with a clean-cut wound and has a history of receiving a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. Based on the guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis, the appropriate management for this patient falls under the category where the patient has received a complete course of tetanus vaccination more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years ago.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:

 

 

CC = Complete course; TIG = Tetanus Immunoglobulin

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the effect of Dietary modification on Serum cholesterol. A group of 100 people were chosen. Their mean cholesterol levels were measured before and after dietary modification. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Paired student’s t-test

 

The paired student’s t-test is used when comparing the means of two related groups, specifically when data is collected from the same individuals before and after an intervention. In this question, the study measures serum cholesterol levels before and after dietary modification in the same group of people, making the data paired. This test is ideal for assessing whether the mean difference between the paired observations (pre- and post-intervention) is statistically significant.

 

Since the data is quantitative and normally distributed, a parametric test such as the paired t-test is appropriate. The paired t-test accounts for the fact that each participant has two related measurements (before and after), which reduces variability compared to independent measurements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Odds Ratio:  This option is incorrect because the odds ratio is used to measure the association between two categorical variables, not for comparing means of quantitative data.

 

Option B. Chi-square test:  This test is used to compare categorical data and is not suitable for comparing means of quantitative measurements.

 

Option D. McNemar test:  This test is used to analyze paired categorical data, specifically for before-and-after studies with binary outcomes, not for comparing continuous variables like cholesterol levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The paired student’s t-test is the appropriate statistical test for comparing means of paired quantitative data collected from the same group before and after an intervention.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male travels frequently and has food during his travels. He presents to PHC OPD with abdominal pain, fever for 4 days. He has bradycardia too. Test for confirmation of diagnosis: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood culture

 

The clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of enteric fever (typhoid), characterized by abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia. The appropriate diagnostic test depends on the stage of the illness:

 

Blood culture is the test of choice from the first week of illness onwards. It remains the most reliable test in the initial stages (within the first week of symptoms) to confirm typhoid fever. This test directly detects the presence of Salmonella bacteria in the blood, making it the most accurate diagnostic method during early illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella and is typically used from the second week of illness onwards. It is not the preferred test during the first week as antibodies may not yet be present in detectable quantities.

 

Option C. Stool culture: This is used from the third week of illness onwards and detects Salmonella in the gastrointestinal tract. It is not suitable for early diagnosis as it becomes positive later in the disease course.

 

Option D. Urine culture: This is used from the fourth week of illness onwards. It detects Salmonella excreted in the urine, but like stool culture, it is useful later in the course of the disease and not for initial diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For typhoid fever diagnosis in the first week of illness, blood culture is the most appropriate and reliable test.

 

Mnemonic – BASU

 

Blood culture – 1st week onwards

Antibody test (Widal) – 2nd week onwards

Stool culture – 3rd week onwards

Urine culture – 4th week onwards

questions.text: True regarding Oral Cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Bivalent with 2 doses

 

The oral cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is a bivalent vaccine designed to protect against serotypes O1 and O139 of the cholera bacteria. It is administered as 2 liquid doses for individuals aged 1 year and older, with a booster dose recommended every 2 years. The vaccine does not contain subunit B antitoxin; hence it does not require a buffer during administration.

 

Educational Objective:


CHOLERA ORAL VACCINES:

 

  •  Dukoral (WC-rBS): Monovalent, V cholera O1 plus Recombinant Toxin B subunit.
    • 2 doses (if age ≥6 years) and booster once/ 2 years
    • 3 doses (if age b/w 2-5 years) and booster dose once per 6 months.
  •  Sanchol and mORCVAX: Bivalent, Serogroups O1 & O139, No toxin B subunit, No buffer required. 2 liquid doses after the age of 1 year and booster after 2 years.
  • Euvichol: it is just like Sanchol. Bivalent with 2 doses.

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The medial rectus muscle is the one highlighted in the provided CT picture. The oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus adjacent to the red nucleus, supplies the medial rectus.

 

The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of:

 

  • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus.
  • Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the diencephalon and is closely associated with the basal ganglia circuitry. It plays a role in motor control. It's not directly associated with the oculomotor nerve's origin.

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract: The decussation of the pyramidal tract (motor fibers) occurs in the lower medulla oblongata, well below the level of the oculomotor nerve's origin. This is where the majority of motor fibers from one hemisphere cross to the opposite side.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: The olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is primarily associated with the coordination of motor tasks. Again, it's located caudally relative to the oculomotor nerve's origin in the midbrain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the anterior aspect of the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus. Its nucleus is situated ventral to the cerebral aqueduct and in close proximity to the red nucleus. Hence, the oculomotor nerve is often associated with the level of the red nucleus in the midbrain. It exits the midbrain medial to the cerebral peduncle.

choices.text: Remove IUD gently, then do MTP

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman had an IUD inserted at a PHC. After a few months, she conceives. On examination, the IUD is still in place. She wants to continue with her pregnancy. Next best step of management is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Remove IUD gently

 

In cases where a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine device (IUD) still in place and wishes to continue with the pregnancy, the standard approach is to gently remove the IUD if the threads are visible and accessible. Removal of the IUD reduces the risk of complications such as infection, preterm labor, and spontaneous abortion. Gently pulling the IUD threads minimizes trauma and associated risks.

 

However, it is important to counsel the patient about the increased risk of spontaneous abortion even after the removal of the IUD, but removal is generally recommended to avoid ongoing complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove IUD gently, then do MTP: This is incorrect because performing Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is not mandatory and cannot be enforced unless the patient chooses it. The primary goal here is to safely remove the IUD, not to proceed directly with MTP.

 

Option C. Do MTP directly: This option is incorrect because the patient explicitly wants to continue the pregnancy. MTP should not be performed without the patient’s consent, and it is not a management step in this case unless requested by the patient.

 

Option D. Leave IUD in situ: Leaving the IUD in place is not advisable as it poses a high risk of adverse outcomes, including infections, miscarriage, and preterm birth. The safest option is to remove the IUD if possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a woman conceives with an IUD in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUD should be gently removed to minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted to decompress the stomach. However, the patient remains conscious and alert during the procedure. What is the best position to place the patient in during the insertion of the NG tube? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

 

  • Among the given conditions, maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.
  • Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified based on their location and volume of daily output.
  • Proximal fistulas have higher output and are associated with greater fluid, electrolyte, and digestive capacity loss.
  • Distal fistulas have lower output and are easier to manage, with a higher likelihood of spontaneous closure.
  • Duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 liters of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts, making them more susceptible to electrolyte imbalances than gastric fistulas.
  • The management of enterocutaneous fistulas follows the SNAP principles:
    • S: Sepsis elimination and skin protection
    • N: A period of parenteral nutrition may be required
    • A: Anatomical assessment
    • P: Definitive planned surgery.

 

A duodenal fistula involves a connection between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and an unintended location, such as the abdominal cavity. This can result in severe malnutrition because the duodenum is a critical site for nutrient absorption in the digestive process. A duodenal fistula can lead to the loss of digestive juices and nutrients, significantly impacting a patient's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic fistula: A pancreatic fistula is a complication where pancreatic fluids leak from the surgical site. While it can lead to malnutrition due to the loss of digestive enzymes, it is not typically as severe as a duodenal fistula in causing malnutrition.

 

Option C. Distal ileal fistula: While a distal ileal fistula can disrupt nutrient absorption to some extent, it is not as critical as a duodenal fistula in terms of causing maximum malnutrition. The ileum is further down the small intestine, and its role in nutrient absorption is not as central as that of the duodenum.

 

Option D. Colonic fistula: A colonic fistula may lead to the loss of stool and fluids but is not primarily responsible for causing severe malnutrition in the same way as a duodenal fistula. The colon's main function is to absorb water and electrolytes, not nutrients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Primary health center

 

  • In India, the School Health Committee recommended that school health services be integrated with general health services, which are managed by primary health centers (PHCs).
  • To ensure effective implementation, the committee proposed the formation of school health committees at various levels. PHCs are responsible for providing a range of school health services such as health assessments, vision and hearing tests, dental check-ups, treatment for common illnesses, immunization, micronutrient management, deworming, and provision of mid-day meals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) QALY

 

Quality Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)

 

  • QALY is a measure of both quality and quantity of life lived
  • QALY is years of life lived in perfect health
  • QALY is used in assessing the value of money of a medical intervention
  • QALY calculation is simple: the change in utility value induced by the treatment is multiplied by the duration of the treatment effect to provide the number of QALYs gained

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HALE: Health-adjusted life expectancy - equivalent number of years in “full health” that a new-born can expect to live based on current rates of ill health and mortality

 

Option B. DALY: Is disability-adjusted life years, which is the best measure of disease burden, including both reduction in life expectancy and diminished quality of life. It can measure both mortality and disability together.

 

DALY = YLL (years of life lost) + YLD (years lost to disability)

 

Option C.  Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy): Means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

choices.text: Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman
Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman

questions.text: G5P4 lady with 4 female children reports for the first time at 18 weeks POG. As per the PCPNDT Act and Beti Bachao Andolan, what will you do? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Do USG, don’t see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman

 

In India, the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, 1994, strictly prohibits the determination of fetal sex to prevent female feticide. The act is a legal measure to curb the misuse of diagnostic techniques for sex determination, which could lead to gender-selective abortions. This law aligns with the Beti Bachao Beti Padhao initiative, which aims to save and educate the girl child.

 

In the given scenario, the woman is at 18 weeks of gestation. A USG (ultrasound) scan is recommended to assess fetal health and pregnancy progress but not to determine the fetus's gender. Neither the radiologist nor the obstetrician/gynecologist should attempt to determine or disclose the fetus's gender unless there is a valid legal or medical reason, which is rare and strictly controlled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Don’t do the USG scan: This option is incorrect because USG is an important tool for monitoring fetal development and maternal health. Refusing to perform a USG scan without medical justification would be inappropriate and neglectful of standard prenatal care.

 

Option C. Do USG, see the fetus gender and don’t tell the woman:  This option is incorrect because, under the PCPNDT Act, healthcare professionals are prohibited from determining the gender of the fetus during a USG scan unless medically indicated. Viewing the fetus's gender without a valid reason is a violation of the law.

 

Option D.  Do USG, see the fetus gender and tell the woman: This option is incorrect and illegal as per the PCPNDT Act. Disclosing the gender of the fetus to the expectant mother or any other person is punishable by law, as it could lead to gender-based discrimination and sex-selective abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal sex determination and disclosure are illegal under the PCPNDT Act unless medically indicated. During routine prenatal care, USG should be performed without determining or revealing the fetus's gender.

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

A. Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.

 

 

B. Central: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. The collapse may be a ‘wedging’ or ‘concertina’ collapse; wedging being more common.

 

C. Anterior: In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.

 

D. Posterior: This is the least common type. In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra, i.e., the pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process are affected.

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common > central type > anterior type > appendiceal type (involving pedicle, lamina, and less commonly transverse process, 2nd least common is spinous process and rarest variety is synovitis of facet joints).
  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of  neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Psoas abscess can give rise to pseudo-hip flexion deformity
  • Paraplegia occurs most often in upper thoracic region.∙
  • Early onset paresis is due to inflammatory edema, granulation tissue, an abscess, caseous material. It has good prognosis.
  • Late onset paresis is due to increasing deformity or reactivation of disease, bony sequestrum, stenosis of the vertebral canal, fibrosis or vascular insufficiency and has poor prognosis.
  • Sequelae of TB spine is usually bony ankylosis.

 

  • Imaging:
  • Plain radiograph: 
    • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
    • Reduction of disc space
    • Vertebral body destruction
    • Paravertebral abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.
    • Widening of mediastinum
       
  • CT scan: 
    • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
       
  • MRI:
    • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
    • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

  • Biopsy:
    • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.

 

  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: no neural complaint; increased reflexes
    • Stage 2: weakness but can walk with support
    • Stage 3: non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%
    • Stage 4: bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%
       
       
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on non-operative management but if indications of surgery exists  then, surgery needs to be done.
    • Stage-wise Treatment:
      • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly neural examination
      • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly neural examination
      • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily neural examination
      • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting
         
    • ATT: 
      • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
      • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
         
    • Indications of surgery: 
      • Bowel bladder involvement
      • Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
      • No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
         
  • Surgical options for most of the cases aren anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed)

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
     

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.
